original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - William Street
text:
1-3 South William Street (right), at the S.E. corner of William Street (left), showing the 11-story Maritime Agency Building. This building occupies the entire block front, between South William and Stone Streets. Beyond same, appears a portion of the 3-story India House, which faces on Hanover Square.

?

Edwin Levick.

Beaver Street, south side, east from William, to and including Pearl Streets. Also shown is William Street, at the S.E. corner of Beaver Street. Building shown is the N.Y. Cotton Exchange.

About 1890.

C. L. Ritzmann.

Beaver Street, south side, east from William, to and including Pearl Streets. Also shown is William Street, east side, south from and including Beaver Street, to but not including Hanover Square. Building concerned is the New York Cotton Exchange fronting on William Street, between Beaver Street and Hanover Square.

About 1890.

P. L. Sperr.
(Taken by August Loeffler)

(1) 60 Beaver Street, southeast corner and William Street, showing New York Cotton Exchange.

(2) Broad Street, northeast corner of Beaver Street, before demolition.

George L. Balgue

View 1: 1922
View 2: 1910

(1) 60 Beaver Street, southeast corner and William Street, showing New York Cotton Exchange.

(2) Broad Street, northeast corner of Beaver Street, before demolition.

George L. Balgue

View 1: 1922
View 2: 1910

At the intersection of Beaver and South William Streets, at William Street on the right, is Beaver Street, south side, west from William, to but not including New Streets. Also shown is South William Street, west from William, to, but not including Broad Streets. Building at the intersection is the Merchant Marine House, formerly "Delmonico's".

About 1920.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

original_title: Manhattan: William Street - South William Street
text:
(1)

William Street, south from and including South William Street. Showing prominently the 11-story Maritime Agency Building, No. 1-3 South William Street. William Street at that point veers to the left and proceeds in an eastward direction.

August 20, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.
Neg. * 1750

(2)

A view slightly westward and showing the curved apex of the Merchant Marine House, formerly Delmonico's, at the convergence of South William and Beaver Streets. The Maritime Agency appears on the extreme left. Nos. 5-7 and 9 South William Street, two low buildings, appear on opposite corners of Mill Lane; the first being occupied by Chubb and Son.

About 1923.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

Beaver Street, east from and across William Street, showing prominently the new 35 story Wall and Hanover Building. This fronts on Hanover Street, extending from Beaver to Wall Street. At the rear of same and occupying the apex of this triangular block is the 25 story Munson S. S. Line Building. This point is where Beaver Street converges with Wall Street. Note excavation work in the foreground of View 2 where former low buildings of the Farmers Loan and Trust Co. and the Canadian Bank of Commerce stood. Upon this site will rise the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co. Building. These views are taken from the Kerr Building, at No. 38-46 Beaver Street and are across the low triangular roof of the Merchant Marine Hotel (formerly Delmonicos). P. L. Sperr  View 1: August 20, 1929 View 2: October 5, 1929

Upon this site will rise the 59 story City Bank Farmers Trust Co. Building. These views are taken from the Kerr Building, at No. 38-46 Beaver Street and are across the low triangular roof of the Merchant Marine Hotel (formerly Delmonicos). P. L. 22 William Street, east side, from Beaver Street to Exchange Place, showing the lower portion of the 59-storied City Bank Farmers Trust Co. occupying this entire block and known by the above location. This view is in a southward direction and shows fortress like square structure of the National City Bank in the foreground which also borders on this street. Photographers vantage point was the 70-storied Bank of Manhattan Building, at No. 40 Wall Street, which permitted a perspective of the confluence of the East and North Rivers, at the Upper Bay; the latter with Governors Island therein. This set of 3 views shows different portions of this new edifice.

March 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

1936.

title: Beaver Street #60 - William Street, southeast corner

text:
Cotton Exchange Building, junction of Beaver & William streets at Hanover Square. Awarded first prize for new building 1923 by Committee of Downtown League comprised of Charles F. Noyes, Chairman, Walter B. Chambers and the late Raymond P. Roberts.

No date.

original_title: Manhattan: South William Street - Beaver Street
text:
South William , Beaver & William Sts.

Merchant Marine House, 9 story building on plot of nearly 6,00 square feet and valued at approximately $1,250,000, purchased by Cecil P. Stewart for his companies a few years a go, and resold by Mr. Stewart reserves leases for fee to the Insurance Company of North America. Mr. Stewart reserves leases for four floors for a long term of years and besides makes the largest profit for the owners that has been made on any real estate "turn" in the neighborhood. Charles F. Noyes Company were the brokers who sold the property.

Date: 1929
52502
Edwin Levick, photographic Illustrations, 108 Fulton St., NY

A general view of the lower East Side of Manhattan as photographed northeastward from the Tribune Bldg. (belief of the writer), showing the area above the future Brooklyn Bridge Approach. The latter will be constructed across the foreground necessitating the demolition of some of the low structures shown. This will be slightly north of Frankfort Street and across the apex of the point of convergence of North William and William Streets. Note the wall sign of Kraft & Hoffmeister there. The Pulitzer Bldg. (World Bldg.) of 1889 will rise on the site of the nonde-script buildings in the left foreground. At the left margin is Park Row and its "El" line. The institutional building in the center midground is the Newsboys Lodging House. To the right is the school and spires of St. James R.C. Church. Madison Street is observable there.

Betw. 1875 - 84

E. L. Armbruster Collection
title: General view - East side of Lower Manhattan.
